Located 18 miles (29 km) east of Edinburgh
column2: and sited on both sides of the River Tyne. Haddington was one of Scotland's first Royal Burghs (created sometime between 1124 and 1153) and was long the namesake of East Lothian (Haddingtonshire). It has a medieval triangle of streets (Court Street
column5: and several preserved buildings from the 17th through to the 19th centuries (the Town House
column9:
and the Corn Exchange). The Nungate Bridge still has an iron hook from which criminals were hung.

It is also referred to as the 'Lamp of Lothian'
column10: originating from the same title given to a Franciscan church in the history of Scotichronicon
column11: and destroyed in 1356. Others have referred to the 14th-century Church of St Mary as the 'Lamp of Lothian'
column12:
possibly for its red sandstone and its earlier crown steeple. Known as Scotland's 'largest parish church' it was damaged in 1548 and a significant part of the building left in ruins until the 1970s.

John Knox grew up here
column13: frequently hearing the reformer George Wishart preach. Jane Welsh Carlyle
column16:
as was Samuel Smiles (1812-1904) of 'self-help' fame.

There is an 18-hole golf course at Amisfield Park.
